intro: Valeriana montana subsp. ambigua, commonly known as the mountain valerian, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central and South America. It typically grows in rocky or well-drained soils and thrives in temperate to cool climates. The plant features slender, upright stems with alternate, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small, clustered in dense spikes, and are usually pink or white in color. It is valued for its aromatic foliage and has been used in traditional medicine for its sedative properties.
